data.title: Logan Marr And Her Murder Essay - 579 Words
data.text:
The story of Logan Marr and her murder is a sad story that should be taught to all child protective service workers and social workers everywhere so the same mistakes are not repeated. However, when establishing who is at fault for Logan's death in this case I think everyone is partially at fault. Logan's mother could have tried harder to get her life in order and regain custody of Logan but she waited until it was too late. The newly employed CPS worker Allison Peters should never have been investigating a case that was already closed based off of an unreliable rumor and she should have also reacted to Logan's signals of distress that she was sending to her mother at their meetings. Sally should have known better on how to treat disruptive children because she had worked in the DHS for many years before adopting Logan. Because the murder of Logan involved two DHS workers the failure to protect Logan ultimately ends with the DHS and the state because they assured Logan's mother that she would be safer under their custody which was not true and they broke a known rule by placing her with someone who worked within the system. …show more content…

First, the DHS needed to be stricter within their guidelines on adoptions and never let Logan stay with Sally. Secondly, I think the DHS needs to be required to have more concrete evidence before invading a home and taking a child from their birth mother. The fact that Logan was taken the last time because of a rumor is not okay and Allison Peters should have been held accountable for that. Last of all, the DHS should have monitored Logan's life with Sally more closely and responded when Logan expressed that Sally was hurting her and her sister quite
